nfadfa.description: The fundamental difference between Non-Deterministic Finite Automata (NFA) and Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA) is that the NFA may have multiple edges coming out of a given node with the same symbol.
nfadfa.question: Is every DFA an NFA?
correctFeedback: Just because an NFA is permitted to have a state in which there are choices on what to do when it sees a given letter, that does not mean that it must do that. So, every DFA is also an NFA. This will be important later.

def.description:
Define a NFA as $(Q, \Sigma, \delta, Q_0, F)$ where
$Q$ is a finite set of states
$\Sigma$ is the input alphabet (a finite set)
$\delta: Q \times(\Sigma \cup \{\lambda\}) \rightarrow 2^Q$ ($2^Q$ here means the power set of $Q$)
$Q_0$ is the intial state ($q_0 \in Q$)
$F \subseteq Q$ is a set of final states.
def.question: What part of the definition for the NFA is different from definition for the DFA?

multi.description: While the result of $\delta$ for the DFA is some state $q \in Q$, the result of $\delta$ for the NFA is any subset of Q
multi.question: The NFA can have a state with 2 transitions for the same input symbol.

moretrans.description: While the result of $\delta$ for the DFA is some state $q \in Q$, the result of $\delta$ for the NFA is any subset of Q
moretrans.question: The NFA cannot have 3 or more transitions from a state using the same input alphabet.

choices.description: Non-deterministic means that it allows choices. From a state on input $b$, $\delta$ might include transitions to more than one state.
choices.question: The NFA's state can always be determined.
correctFeedback: Though it depends a little bit on what you mean by 'determined'. You can't know the single state that the machine will transition to in a given situation. But you can know the set of possible states that the machine could go to.

nfaexamp.description: In the NFA below, there are two choices when the machine sees 'a' when it is in state q0. So, $\delta(q0, a) = \{q1, q2\}$.
nfaexamp.question: What are the possible states to transition to when the machine is in q0 and sees the symbol 'a'?

badb.description: In the NFA below, there are two choices when the machine sees 'a' when it is in state q0. So, $\delta(q0, a) = \{q1, q2\}$.
badb.question: What are the possible states to transition to when the machine is in q0 and sees the symbol 'b'?

lambda.description: A $\lambda$ transition is a 'free ride' to another state without any input.
lambda.question: A $\lambda$ transition does not consume a symbol when it moves to the new state.

multilambda.description: A $\lambda$ transition is a 'free ride' to another state without any input.
multilambda.question: A $\lambda$ transition cannot be immediately followed by another $\lambda$ transition to yet another state.
correctFeedback: Potentially, the machine might allow a whole series of 'free ride' $\lambda$ transitions before the next symbol is processed.

starting.description: A $\lambda$ transition is a 'free ride' to another state without any input.
starting.question: Which state(s) might this NFA be in when it processes the first input symbol?

firstletter.description: A $\lambda$ transition is a 'free ride' to another state without any input.
firstletter.question: Which state(s) can the NFA be in after processing the first letter of a string that starts with 'a'?

walk.description: Definition: $q_j \in \delta^*(q_i, w)$ if and only if there exists some walk from $q_i$ to $q_j$ where $w$ is a string. Note that in this definition, while $w$ is a string, it is not necessarily the entire input to the machine. This definition just refers to states that can be reached from $q_i$ when processing $w$. And if $w$ is three symbols, then that means transitioning over (at least) three edges (one for each symbol, and maybe some $\lambda$ transitions).
walk.question: What is $\delta^*(q_0, ab)$?

formalaccept.description:
We now have the notation and concepts that we need to provide a formal definition for the language of a NFA. For any NFA $M$,
$L(M)= \{w \in {\Sigma}^{*} \mid \delta^{*}(q_0,w) \cap F \neq \emptyset \}$
This means that the machine accepts all strings $w$ from the set of all possible strings (generated from the alphabet $\Sigma$) such that some state reachable on $w$ from the start state ($q_0$) is a final state.
formalaccept.question: When $w =ab$, how many accepting paths exist?

acceptreject.description: The NFA tries every acceptable walk from the start state for the given input. From that set of possible paths, if any ends in a state that is final, then the NFA will ACCEPT the input. If that set is empty (not possible to make a path using this input), or those path(s) do not end in a final state, the NFA will REJECT.
acceptreject.question: A NFA ACCEPTS when every possible walk for the input string ends in a final state.
correctFeedback: Correct! If 10 possible walks exist, and only one ends in a final state, then the NFA will ACCEPT. It ignores all failure wals.
